titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. We intended to have started this morning, by six O’clock, but it was eight, before we could get ready, and enter the carriage— Mr: Shaw went with us, untill we found Mr: Otis waiting for us, at the top of Milton Hill, at the parting of the Roads by Mr: Robbins’s house— Mr: Shaw then took Mr: Otis’s chaise, to carry back to Boston, and Mr: Otis joined us— We came to Attleborough to dinner, and at about 7 in the Evening safely arrived at Providence— We took up our lodgings at Ammidon’s, on the top of the Hill—

2. During the prevalence of the malignant fever which rages at New-York, the intercourse between this place and that city by the Packets is suspended— Captain Anthony however has agreed to send his sloop the Cordelia, to land us at Powles Hook, and agreed to sail to-morrow, if the wind will permit— I went with Mr: Otis this forenoon to the congregational meeting-house, and heard Mr: Abbot; and in the afternoon, to the episcopal Church, where we heard a young Mr: Crocker— Walked afterwards round the town— Mr: Theodore Foster, Judge Barnes and Mr: Ward called upon us in the Evening.

3. Our Captain found it impracticable to sail this day, which was entirely calm, and the weather very warm— Mr: Otis, who thought he could not venture the risque of further delay, concluded to proceed in the mail-stage, which went on this day, at about 1. P.M. The rest of us remained at Providence. In the evening Judge Bourne alighted at the house where we lodge— And pass’d an hour with me; as did Mr: Bronson, who came this day from Newport— Judge Barnes likewise called— This evening, a man by the name of James Brown entered into conversation with me; by the strangeness of which it became very soon evident that his intellects were disordered. He talks of nothing less than totally changing the face of the world, natural, political and moral— And his first conquest is to be over lee-way.

4. At nine this morning, we embarked on board the Packet Cordelia, Captain Crepon (for Captain Anthony does not go with us himself)— We had a thickening, cloudy and rainy day; growing all the afternoon to a North-east storm— Mr: Brown, the man of new organizations, came with us; between four and five in the afternoon we arrived at Newport; and concluded to put up for the night, at Mr: Brinton’s, where we lodged when we came from New-York in November 1801— He has moved into another house; more distant from the wharf where the packets usually lay— Mr: Hore, an Englishman who took passage with us, came to the same lodgings— We had also a french family, from St: Domingo; of two men, two women, and two children, very nearly of the age of ours— But they remain on board the Packet—

5. We could not proceed yesterday, though with a perfectly fair wind, because we had foul weather; and this day we cannot sail, though with fair weather; because we have a foul wind. This double inconvenience almost always occurs in attempting to go this way from Boston to New-York; which I shall not willingly do again— This is the third time I have made the experiment— And twice I have been detained four or five days at Providence and Newport— I shall think myself very fortunate to be delayed no longer this time— This is already the third lost day— The convenience is much greater in coming from New-York by this way; and for the future I think I shall traverse the Sound only in the direction Eastward.— The last Night was extremely boisterous, and this day has been equally so— Provided George with a pair of shoes instead of those he yesterday threw over-board— Was on board the Packet this forenoon, vainly urging our Captain to sail— Pass’d the day in tedious expectation of the morrow— Walk’d out with Mrs: Adams this afternoon— Read a few pages in Langhorne’s Plutarch— The life of Romulus.

6. After a boisterous night, we have the wind this morning directly a-head, as it was yesterday. I made some inquiry for a carriage to go on by land to New-London; but the roads are so bad, that I could not procure one; so we were compelled to take patience for another day of delay— I spent the forenoon principally in writing; and the afternoon in reading Plutarch’s life of Lycurgus.

7. This morning before Sun-rise there was a very light breeze from the North-east— I went with Mr: Hoare down to the Packet, and finally prevailed upon the Captain to sail— We quitted the wharf just at eight o’clock but the North-eastern breeze was already gone. We made our way to Point Judith in a couple of hours, and then found a head wind, which compell’d us to take our course on the outer-side of Block Island. The breeze was light untill shortly before Sun-set, when it suddenly freshened almost to a gale— A heavy Sea, arose— Almost every body on board became Sea-sick, our jib-stay broke, and we were obliged to lay to a couple of hour’s to repair it. We continued beating between Fisher’s island and Long island, the whole Night, which was extremely boisterous, though with a clear sky— We all suffered much; but my wife with her infant whom she was obliged to keep in one of the very small births of the Packet, while George was laying, continually Sea-sick, all night in another close at her side was more distress’d than the rest of us. I was up the whole night.

8. This morning, the wind continuing violent, and the sea very high, we found it quite useless to struggle longer against them, and persuaded our Captain to put in to New-London. We landed at the wharf, between 7 and 8 o’clock; and after breakfasting went on shore, and took chambers at Frink’s Tavern & Coffee-House. Here we remained the rest of the day; and at night had retired to bed in expectation of passing it quietly when we were summoned again on board the Packet; the wind having become favourable to the progress of our voyage— We therefore embarked again between 11 and 12 at Night, and sailed in company with the two Sisters Captain Earle, another of the Newport Packets, which left that place the Night before us, and after having proceeded fifty miles farther than we had, was obliged to come back here, and had come in this morning about two hours after us.

9. After an easy, and pleasant run of fifteen hours, we landed at Powles Hoek, and immediately took a carriage, to Gifford’s tavern at Newark—9 miles. We arrived between 5 and 6. in the afternoon, and with no small difficulty obtained a single chamber to lodge the whole family. The town and the house are so much crowded, by the inhabitants fled from the yellow-fever at New-York, that it is scarcely possible to find a chamber unoccupied— We had scarcely quitted the Carriage, and entered the house, when my wife, whose constitution is not strong enough to endure the violent fatigue, and agitation she has gone through the last three days, was suddenly seized with an extremely violent fever— I immediately sent for a physician, Doctor Johnson, who came, and gave her a powerful opiate, which produced the effect of laying her asleep, which continued with intervals of extreme illness the whole night— I called on Mrs: Smith’s at the house where she now lives, after going to that where she formerly resided— She invited me to her house, and to bring the family with me; but our family is too large, and my wife was too ill to be removed— I found here Coll: Pickering, Mr: Cutler, Mr: Taggart, and a Mr: Chamberlain of Vermont, members of Congress, going on to-morrow.

10. My wife continued very ill the whole day. But her fever has been subsiding, and leaves her extremely weak: Mrs: Smith and Mrs: C. Adams called to see her in the morning— Mr: and Mrs: Meredith and Mrs: Hawkins called also this afternoon, but she was not able to see them— I carried George to Mrs: Smith’s, where he pass’d the day. Mrs: Adams with Nancy Smith brought him back in the afternoon.

11. We are still detained by my wife’s illness— Her fever though much abated is not yet completely subdued. Coll: Smith called to see us in the morning— I carried George again to Mrs: Smith’s, and brought him back at night. Coll: Smith has brought his daughter with him here.

12. My wife’s fever having entirely subsided, we left Gifford’s at Newark this day at noon, and came on six miles to Elizabeth-Town, and stop’d at Lyon’s tavern. Gifford sent us on in a light, easy carriage of his own. An extra stage is to come one to-morrow if the day be fair, and if not the next day, to take us in two days to Frankfort.— Mrs: Adams though very weak, supported the ride very well, and appears to be rapidly recovering.— They are now holding their elections in this State— In the afternoon I took a walk, and went into the Hall where the poll is opened. There were a number of people about the house; all apparently warmly interested in the event.

13. The weather threatened to be foul this morning, and our Stage did not come from Newark for us. We therefore pass’d the day at Elizabeth-Town— Here I saw Mr: Pintard of New-York, who is going on to Georgia for his health— He went away about noon; the weather having cleared up. It is much warmer than I have ever known it so late in the Season at Boston.

14. The day being very fine, the Stage from General Cumming’s at Newark, came and took us up, at 1/2 past 9 this morning. They are to carry us on as far as Frankford.— We came twenty miles to Brunswick, where we dined, and then 18 to Princeton— My wife on arriving, went immediately to bed— She is still very weak.

15. At 1/2 past eight this morning, we left Princeton, in a Stage and Horses which came from Kingstown 3 miles back and took us up— We rode twelve miles to Trenton, and then ten to Bristol, where we dined. Here I found a letter from my brother, who left the place not an hour before we arrived— He returned into the City— After dinner we came on fifteen miles to Frankford; where we could not find accommodations to lodge— The place being crowded with fugitives from Philadelphia, as Newark is with those from New-York. At length we procured lodgings at Dover’s— The Rising Sun— Just over the Bridge, and in the Northern Liberties of Philadelphia— When we had got well settled, I went to enquire for a mode of proceeding on our Journey— I found we had only the alternative of going round to Gray’s ferry, and there taking the Stage, to travel Night and day— Or of sending in to Philadelphia, for a private Carriage and Horses to take us on from this place— I preferr’d the latter of these modes, and wrote in to my brother to engage us a Carriage and Horses, to come for us early on Monday Morning. Mr: Patten the Post-Master, promised to have the letter to my brother delivered to-morrow morning— We had a rainy morning; but the weather cleared away wholly fair in the afternoon. Mrs: Adams continues quite unwell; but has borne the journey from Elizabeth-Town, beyond expectation.

16. I went to the Baptist meeting-house, and heard Dr: Rogers of Philadelphia. The house was very much crowded. As I came out, from it, I found my brother waiting for me. He dined with us. Mr: Ewen and Mr: Nicholls of Philadelphia, called and pass’d an hour with us in the evening— My brother returned to Philadelphia in the Evening, and comes out in a carriage he has engaged for us, to-morrow morning.

17. Between 8 and 9 this morning, my brother came out in a carriage from Philadelphia; with a pair of horses; which took us round without entering within the limits of the City; untill we came to the middle ferry. There we took four fresh horses, and my brother accompanied us to Chester where we dined— My brother there took leave of us and we came to Wilmington to lodge— At the middle ferry I saw the workmen at the permanent Bridge, which they are carrying over the Schuylkill— They are also making a Turnpike from Philadelphia to New-York.

18. We left Wilmington this morning at 1/2 past eight and came through Newport, Christine and Elkton, where we dined, to the Susquehannah, which we cross’d between Sunset and dark. We lodge at Havre-de-Grace— The public houses on this road are very good; but the roads are indifferent; and the soil of the Country poor, and very miserably cultivated.

19. This morning soon after 8 we started from Havre de Grace, and after riding about 35 miles arrived just about dusk at Baltimore— We expected to have been stop’d, short of the City by a health officer; in consequence of the regulation prohibiting the entrance here of persons from Philadelphia or New-York; but no such officer is thus stationed, and the regulation itself is rather a menace in terrorem, than an effectual exclusion of persons from the sickly cities— We could not procure lodgings at Evans’s— His house being already full; but he obtained admission for us at Mrs: Grey’s—a private boarding house, where the accomodations however are very poor.

20. Evans furnished us this morning an extra-Stage, in which we left Baltimore at 1/2 past 8, and arrived at Washington just at dusk in the Evening. Our journey was unpleasant this day on Account of the dust, with which we have not been troubled before. As we came in to the City of Washington we met Mr: Otis in a carriage going from the President’s House to the Capitol— Immediately after we arrived I received a card from him, with some letters, and mentioning that he had been when we met him to the President’s to carry the Advice of the Senate to the ratification of the Treaty for the cession of Louisiana, which pass’d in the Senate 24 yeas and 7. nays— We came to Mr: Hellen’s, where we found Mrs: Johnson, and her family— All well; excepting Mrs: Hellen, who is extremely ill.

21. At 11. this morning, I took my seat in the Senate of the United States, after delivering my credential letter to Mr: Otis the Secretary; and being sworn to support the Constitution of the United States, by Mr: John Brown of Kentucky, who is the President pro tem:— Mr: Burr, the Vice-President being absent. There was little business done, and the Senate adjourned soon after 12.— Mr: Otis is much alarmed, at the prospect of being removed from his Office. It has been signified to him this day, that in order to retain it, he must have all the printing done by Duane— His compliance may possibly preserve him one session longer. After the Senate adjourned, I went in, without the bar of the House of Representatives; but they adjourned immediately afterwards— As I returned home, I called at the President’s, and not finding him at home, left a Card.

22. I called this morning at the Offices of the Secretary of State, and of the Secretary of the Treasury, but found neither of them there— Attended in Senate, where the principal business done was upon a resolution offered by Mr Clinton, for designating in all future elections of President and Vice-President, the persons who are to fill each of those Offices— Several amendments were offered to this resolution, which was finally committed to a select Committee, of five. It was near 3. o’clock when the adjournment took place.

23. There is no church of any denomination at this City, but religious service is usually performed on Sundays at the Treasury-Office, and at the Capitol— I went both forenoon and afternoon to the Treasury, but found there was this day no preaching there, on account of the Indisposition of Mr: Laurie.— The two Senators from Delaware, Messrs: Wells and White, and Mr: Huger a Member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina, called upon me this morning.

24. Called at the Secretary of State’s Office this morning, and had some conversation with him, relative to the settlement of my Accounts during my residence abroad, in the public service— But he still makes difficulties, beyond what I conceive to be reasonable or proper— Called also on the Secretary of the Treasury, but he was not at his Office.
Attended in Senate— The day was spent in debate upon the proposed amendment to the Constitution, respecting the election of President and Vice-President— No decision was had— Some warm expressions pass’d between Mr: Clinton and Mr: Dayton— Dined with Mr: Cranch; who informed me that he was about publishing a volume of Reports of Cases adjudged by the Supreme Court of the United States, in this City.— Returning home I stop’d at the Post-Office, and left a specimen of my signature, as required by Law, for the purpose of franking my letters— The Clerks told me it was unnecessary, as that direction of the Law was almost universally neglected— That only one member of Congress had complied with it this Session— I left however my signature and thus executed the injunction of the law so far as respected myself.

25. I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, but did not find him there— Attended in Senate— Mr: Clinton, who is appointed Mayor of the City of New-York, and will be obliged to be sworn in at the beginning of the next month, went away early this morning— He left an handsome written apology for the expressions he used yesterday, offensive to Mr: Dayton, which was read by Mr: Wright in his place— Mr: Breckinridge’s bill for enabling the President to take possession of Louisiana, was debated at the 2d: reading, and is to be read the third time— Mr: Wright informed the Senate, that the reason why the decision upon the Resolution for amending the Constitution in respect to the election of President, was so vehemently press’d was, because Mr: Clinton the mover wanted to get through with it before he went home— But that as other gentlemen wanted time and the subject was important, he moved the subject be postponed for further consideration untill to-morrow; which was done. He then called up his Resolution for coming to a new choice of Secretary and other Officers of the Senate— But it was determined by a bare majority not to take up the consideration of this Resolution for the present.— Adjourned at about 1. o’clock. P.M— I went in to the House of Representatives, and heard a Mr: Elliot from Vermont for about an hour— Mr: Tracy made me acquainted with Mr: Griswold.— Came home to dinner between 3 and 4. o’clock— After dinner we went with the Ladies on board the ship Cleopatra, which lies below in the river and is going to Amsterdam.— Mr: John Smith, the second Senator from the State of Ohio, this day was sworn and took his seat.

26. Called again at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury without finding him— Saw the Auditor and shewed him the documents which had been required for the settlement of my Accounts— Attended in the Senate. The bill for enabling the President to take possession of Louisiana, and for other purposes, pass’d the 3d: reading— 26. yeas 6 nays. The objection was to the second Section as Unconstitutional— After the bill had pass’d Mr: Breckinridge, who introduced it, had the words for other purposes, in the title altered for the temporary government of the same— We adjourned about 1/2 past two.

27. Attended in Senate, where some private business was done, and the Treaty of limits with Great-Britain was read the second time— Mr: Wright called up his resolution for choosing a Secretary and the other Officers of the Senate; but a motion to postpone the consideration of the Resolution untill the 1st: Monday in October next prevailed. The votes were 17 to 13— Adjourned quite early. I went in to the House of Representatives and heard the debate there on the bill which yesterday pass’d the Senate— The principal speakers were Messrs: Griswold, Eustis, J. Randolph, Eppes, Rodney and Elliot— Home between 4 and 5.— Evening, not very well.

28. called at the Secretary of State’s Office, to give him a letter for Mr: Randolph— Spoke to him also for a copy of Laws and Journals for the Historical Society— I ask’d him whether the Executive had made any arrangements with any member of either house to bring forward the proposal for an Amendment to the Constitution to carry through the Louisiana Treaty— That if any such arrangement was made, I should wait
wait quietly untill it should be produced— But if not, I should think it my duty to move for such an Amendment— He said he did not know that it was universally agreed that it required an Amendment of the Constitution— But for his own part, had he been on the floor of Congress he should have seen no difficulty in acknowledging, that the Constitution had not provided for such a case as this— That it must be estimated by the magnitude of the object, and that those who had agreed to it, must rely upon the candour of their Country for Justification— To all of which I agreed, but urged the necessity of removing as speedily as possible all question on this subject, to which he readily assented— He said he did not know that any arrangement had been made; that probably when the objects of immediate pressure were gone through it would be attended to, and if he should have any agency in concerting the measure, he would request the gentleman who might propose it to consult previously with me.— Attended in Senate.— Mr: Butler’s Resolution for a further Negotiation with France under consideration, debated untill past 3. p.m. when we adjourned— I was unwell in the Evening, and had been indeed so the whole day— Had no rest last Night.

29. In Senate— The debate was upon the bill to enable the President to take possession of Louisiana &c, which comes back from the House with Amendments to the second Section— I moved an amendment to the last Amendment from the house, by an addition of the words “consistently with the Constitution of the U.S.” But it was objected that this was not in order, my proposed amendment referring not to the Amendment from the House, but to the original section of the bill, upon which this House, having already acted could not now act again— The President so decided, but requested the sense of the House which confirmed his decision. The amendments were all rejected, and a Committee of Conference appointed. The House of Rep: insisted— The Conferees met, and agreed, that the Senate should recede from their disagreement to the amendments from the House, and agree to the same, with a further amendment— When our Conferees came in, the Senate agreed to that part of the report which proposed to recede, but disagreed to the additional amendment of their own Conferees— So the bill pass’d as amended in the House of Representatives— It was observed as a rule and on all sides recognized that the Speaker of the House and President of the Senate could not sign an enrolled bill, but while those bodies are respectively in session— Adjourned soon after 3. o’clock.

30. Attended public service at the Capitol, where Mr: Rattoon an Episcopalian Clergyman from Baltimore, preached a sermon.— I afterwards called on Messrs: Wells and White, the Senators from Delaware, but did not find them at their lodgings— Visited also Mr: Amory, and Mr: Pickering, with whom I found a number of the Connecticut and Massachusetts members of Congress.— Walking home I met Mr: Baldwin, with Mr: Morton, who arrived with Mrs: Morton last Evening.— Mr: Baldwin told me, he had called with Mr: Butler to see me— The ladies overtook me soon after, in the Carriage, with which they had been visiting— I went with them to Mr: D. Peter’s, and to Mr: Huger’s, at Georgetown— Captain Blackston dined with us— Afternoon we had a visit from Mr: Otis, and in the evening from Dr: Thornton.

31. In Senate, Mr: Breckinridge, introduced a resolution, to wear crape a month for the three illustrious patriots, Samuel Adams, Edmond Pendleton and Stevens Thompson Mason.— I asked for the Constitutional Authority of the Senate to injoin upon its members this act, and he referred to the manual, that such a regulation was merely conventional, and not binding, upon the members. I then objected against it, as improper in itself, tending to unsuitable discussions of character, and to an employment of the Senate’s time in debates altogether foreign to the
the subjects which properly belong to them— This led to a debate of three hours, in the course of which the resolution was divided into two— One for Mr: Mason, as a matter of form and of course, to a member of the Senate, holding the Office at the time of his decease— The other for the two other illustrious patriots. The first was unanimously agreed to— The last by a majority of 21 to 10— A Message from the President, with several Indian Treaties was then read— And the Treaty of limits with Great Britain, taken up as in Committee of the whole. Mr: Butler proposed an alteration in the 5th: Article, and Mr: S. Smith intimated that since the ratification of the Louisiana Treaty, this one must not be ratified at-all— Adjourned at 1/2 past 3.— I walk’d with Mr: Wells, as far as the President’s House, where he, with several others of the Senators dined.

Day. From the 1st: to the 20th: of this month we were upon our Journey from Quincy to Washington, with the customary irregularity of travelling. Here my mode of life is more uniform— I rise at about 7. Write in my own chamber untill 9. Breakfast— Dress, and soon after ten begin my walk to the Capitol. The distance is two miles and an half, and takes me 45 minutes— I get there soon after 11. and usually find the Senate assembled. We sit untill 2 or 3. and when the adjournment is earlier, I go in and hear the debates in the House of Representatives. Home at 4. dine— And pass the Evening, idly, with George in my chamber, or with the ladies. They sup between 9 and 10.— At 11. is the hour for bed— This great change in the arrangement of my daily occupations and manner of living, has affected my health in some degree, and the interest with which my mind seizes hold of the public business, is greater than suits my comfort or can answer any sort of public utility.
